page.title: Overview
page.introduction:
VCell provides two styles of developing computational models:
BioModels
MathModels
Each uses a different method to create models to best suit a given user's experience.
BioModel A BioModel is a computational model built by defining the biological components of the model within a graphical interface.
BioModels consist of:
(1) A Physiology; the cellular structures, species and biochemical reactions that are components of the model.
(2) Applications; the application of the model to a specific instance of physiology,in which the initial state and any additional conditions or constraints on the physiology are defined.
Each Application allows the user to define the quantitative values needed to define, run and visualize a Virtual Experiment (i.e. numerical simulation). Thus, an Application includes:
Geometry
Specifications (e.g. species, reactions)
Protocols (e.g. events, electrical mapping)
Simulations, of which there can be one or more.
Parameter Estimation (if applicable) for defining parameters based on experimental data
MathModel MathModels create individual Applications (Virtual Experiments) using the Virtual Cell Markup Language (VCML). VCell automatically creates a unique MathModel for each Application within a BioModel; such MathModels can be created ad hoc or edited using VCML. Note that a MathModel does not have an associated Physiology. A MathModel consists of a series of definitions for:
Constants
Variables
Functions
Volume domains
Membrane domains
See Generated Math for more information on the components of the math description and how to create a stand-alone MathModel from an existing BioModel Application that can then be further edited.
